**Solution Explanation**

Let \(V\) be an \(n\)-dimensional real vector space, and let 
\[
L = \mathrm{End}(V) \;=\; \{\text{all linear operators }T:V\to V\}.
\]
We want to exhibit a basis of \(L\) consisting of linear operators each of which is diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\). 

---

## 1. Strategy and Key Idea

A standard way to get a basis of \(\mathrm{End}(V)\) over \(\mathbb{R}\) is to use the set of elementary matrices \(E_{ij}\) (which send the basis vector \(e_j\) to \(e_i\) and all other basis vectors to \(0\)).  However, most \(E_{ij}\) (when \(i\neq j\)) are *not* diagonalizable (even over \(\mathbb{C}\)) because they are nilpotent of index 2.

Instead, one exploits the fact that certain simple symmetric and skew-symmetric real matrices *are* diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\).  Concretely:

1. **Diagonal matrices** over \(\mathbb{R}\) are trivially diagonal (hence diagonalizable) even over \(\mathbb{R}\), so certainly over \(\mathbb{C}\).

2. **Symmetric off-diagonal blocks** of size \(2\times 2\) of the form 
   \[
     \begin{pmatrix}
       0 & 1\\
       1 & 0
     \end{pmatrix}
   \]
   have eigenvalues \(\pm 1\).  Hence they are diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\) (in fact already diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{R}\)).

3. **Skew-symmetric off-diagonal blocks** of size \(2\times 2\) of the form 
   \[
     \begin{pmatrix}
       0 & -1\\
       1 & 0
     \end{pmatrix}
   \]
   have eigenvalues \(\pm i\).  Hence they are diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\) (but *not* over \(\mathbb{R}\)).

From these blocks, one can construct a standard basis of \(\mathrm{End}(V)\) consisting of:

- Diagonal matrices \(E_{ii}\),  
- Symmetric off-diagonal matrices \(E_{ij} + E_{ji}\) for \(i<j\),  
- Skew-symmetric off-diagonal matrices \(E_{ij} - E_{ji}\) for \(i<j\).  

Each such matrix is diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\).  Moreover, these matrices span the whole space \(L\) and are linearly independent, giving the desired basis.

---

## 2. Explicit Construction of the Basis

Fix a real basis \(\{e_1, e_2, \dots, e_n\}\) of \(V\).  With respect to this basis, every linear operator \(T\in L\) can be represented uniquely by an \(n\times n\) real matrix \(\bigl(a_{ij}\bigr)\).  We will construct our basis in block form:

1. **Diagonal part**:  For \(1\le i \le n\), let
   \[
     E_{ii}\colon
     \begin{cases}
       e_i \;\mapsto\; e_i,\\
       e_j \;\mapsto\; 0 \quad (j\neq i).
     \end{cases}
   \]
   In matrix form, \(E_{ii}\) has a \(1\) in the \((i,i)\)-entry and \(0\) elsewhere.  It is already *diagonal*, hence trivially diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\).  
   
   There are \(n\) such operators \(\{E_{11},E_{22},\dots,E_{nn}\}\).

2. **Symmetric off-diagonal part**:  For \(1 \le i < j \le n\), define
   \[
     S_{ij} \;=\; E_{ij} \;+\; E_{ji}.
   \]
   In matrix form, \(S_{ij}\) has a \(1\) in the \((i,j)\)-entry and a \(1\) in the \((j,i)\)-entry, with all other entries \(0\).  When you restrict \(S_{ij}\) to the \(\{e_i, e_j\}\)-plane, its matrix is
   \[
     \begin{pmatrix}
       0 & 1\\
       1 & 0
     \end{pmatrix},
   \]
   which has eigenvalues \(\pm 1\).  Therefore \(S_{ij}\) is diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\) (even over \(\mathbb{R}\)).  

   There are \(\binom{n}{2}\) such operators \(\{S_{ij} : 1\le i<j\le n\}\).

3. **Skew-symmetric off-diagonal part**:  For \(1 \le i < j \le n\), define
   \[
     T_{ij} \;=\; E_{ij} \;-\; E_{ji}.
   \]
   In matrix form, \(T_{ij}\) has a \(1\) in the \((i,j)\)-entry, a \(-1\) in the \((j,i)\)-entry, and all other entries \(0\).  Restricted to the \(\{e_i, e_j\}\)-plane, \(T_{ij}\) is represented by
   \[
     \begin{pmatrix}
       0 & \; -1\\
       1 & \;\;\,0
     \end{pmatrix},
   \]
   which has complex eigenvalues \(\pm i\).  Hence \(T_{ij}\) is also diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\) (but not over \(\mathbb{R}\), since it is a \(90^\circ\)-rotation in that plane).

   There are again \(\binom{n}{2}\) such operators \(\{T_{ij} : 1\le i<j\le n\}\).

Altogether, we have:
\[
\underbrace{n}_{\text{diagonal}} 
\;+\; 
\underbrace{\binom{n}{2}}_{\text{symmetric off-diagonal}} 
\;+\; 
\underbrace{\binom{n}{2}}_{\text{skew-symmetric off-diagonal}}
\;=\;n \;+\; \frac{n(n-1)}{2} \;+\;\frac{n(n-1)}{2}
\;=\;n^2.
\]
This matches the dimension of \(L = \mathrm{End}(V)\).

---

## 3. Verifying Linear Independence and Spanning

1. **Linear independence**:  
   - The operators \(E_{ii}\) are clearly linearly independent from each other.
   - The operators \(S_{ij}\) (\(i<j\)) are linearly independent among themselves because each places nonzero entries in a unique pair of off-diagonal symmetric positions \((i,j)\) and \((j,i)\).
   - The operators \(T_{ij}\) (\(i<j\)) are linearly independent among themselves because each places nonzero entries in a unique pair of off-diagonal skew-symmetric positions.  
   - No nontrivial linear combination of the three types (diagonal, symmetric-off-diagonal, skew-off-diagonal) can cancel out to the zero matrix, because each type “affects” distinct positions (or parity of positions) in the matrix.  

2. **Spanning**:  Any real \(n\times n\) matrix can be decomposed uniquely into a sum of a diagonal part, a symmetric off-diagonal part, and a skew-symmetric off-diagonal part.  Concretely, if \((a_{ij})\) is any matrix:
   \[
   \text{(Diagonal part)} \;=\;\sum_{i} a_{ii}\,E_{ii},
   \]
   \[
   \text{(Symmetric off-diagonal part)} \;=\;\sum_{i<j} \bigl(\tfrac{a_{ij} + a_{ji}}{2}\bigr)\,[\,E_{ij}+E_{ji}\,],
   \]
   \[
   \text{(Skew-symmetric off-diagonal part)} 
   \;=\;\sum_{i<j} \bigl(\tfrac{a_{ij}-a_{ji}}{2}\bigr)\,[\,E_{ij}-E_{ji}\,].
   \]
   Hence every operator in \(\mathrm{End}(V)\) is a real linear combination of the above basis elements.

Therefore, the set
\[
\bigl\{\,E_{11},E_{22},\dots,E_{nn}\bigr\}
\;\cup\;
\bigl\{\,E_{ij} + E_{ji}\;:\;1\le i<j\le n\bigr\}
\;\cup\;
\bigl\{\,E_{ij} - E_{ji}\;:\;1\le i<j\le n\bigr\}
\]
is indeed a basis of \(L = \mathrm{End}(V)\).

---

## 4. Conclusion: Each Basis Element is \(\mathbb{C}\)-Diagonalizable

- \(E_{ii}\) is *already diagonal* with real eigenvalues \(0\) and \(1\).
- \(E_{ij} + E_{ji}\) restricted to \(\mathrm{span}\{e_i,e_j\}\) acts like 
  \(\begin{pmatrix}0 & 1\\1 & 0\end{pmatrix}\),  
  which has eigenvalues \(\pm 1\), hence diagonalizable (even over \(\mathbb{R}\)).
- \(E_{ij} - E_{ji}\) restricted to \(\mathrm{span}\{e_i,e_j\}\) acts like 
  \(\begin{pmatrix}0 & -1\\1 & 0\end{pmatrix}\),  
  which has eigenvalues \(\pm i\), hence diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\).

Thus **all** these basis elements are diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\).  Since they form a basis, we have shown:

> **The space \(\mathrm{End}(V)\) has a basis consisting of real-linear operators that are each diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\).**

This completes the proof.

First, let us restate **the finite-dimensional result** in a nutshell:

> **Finite-dimensional case**:  
> If \(V\) is an \(n\)-dimensional real vector space, then the space \(L = \mathrm{End}(V)\) (all linear operators \(V \to V\)) admits a basis consisting of operators each of which is diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\).  Concretely, one takes as a basis:
> 1. The diagonal matrices \(E_{ii}\).
> 2. The symmetric off-diagonal matrices \(E_{ij} + E_{ji}\) (\(i < j\)).
> 3. The skew-symmetric off-diagonal matrices \(E_{ij} - E_{ji}\) (\(i < j\)).
> 
> Each is diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\) (the skew-symmetric ones have eigenvalues \(\pm i\)).

---

## The Infinite-Dimensional Case

When \(V\) is an **infinite-dimensional** real vector space, say \(\dim(V) = \kappa\) for some infinite cardinal \(\kappa\), the situation changes drastically.  The short answer is:

1. **There is still a “basis” of the space \(L = \mathrm{End}(V)\) in the sense of a Hamel basis** (purely algebraic basis).  
2. **However, the statement “\(L\) has a basis consisting of operators each of which is diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\)” generally fails** for infinite-dimensional \(V\).  

Below are some of the key reasons and stumbling blocks.

---

### 1. Infinite-Dimensional “Diagonalizability”

Over an infinite-dimensional space, an operator \(T: V \to V\) is called **diagonalizable** over \(\mathbb{C}\) if there exists a (Hamel) basis of \(V\) consisting of eigenvectors of \(T\) in \(\mathbb{C}\).  In other words, one can write \(V\) as a direct sum of eigenspaces
\[
V \;=\; \bigoplus_{\lambda \in \sigma(T)} \ker(T - \lambda I)
\]
where \(\sigma(T)\) is the (algebraic) spectrum of \(T\).

- In the finite-dimensional case, this is a matter of finding \(n\) linearly independent eigenvectors if the characteristic polynomial splits.  
- In the infinite-dimensional case, it requires that **every vector** of \(V\) be written as a (finite) linear combination of eigenvectors.  

Many natural operators on infinite-dimensional spaces fail to be diagonalizable.  For example, unilateral or bilateral shift operators (common in functional analysis) have no eigenvalues at all, so they certainly are not diagonalizable.  Even if we stay purely algebraic (no topology assumed), there are many nilpotent or “shift-like” operators on an infinite basis that have large Jordan normal forms with no nontrivial eigenvectors.

---

### 2. The Rank-One (or Finite-Rank) Operators Fail

A common strategy for building a spanning set (or basis) in \(\mathrm{End}(V)\) is to look at finite-rank operators that act like “matrix units” relative to some chosen basis \(\{e_i : i\in I\}\) of \(V\).  For each pair \(i,j\in I\), one considers
\[
E_{ij}(\,e_j\,) \;=\; e_i, 
\quad
E_{ij}(\,e_k\,)=0 \text{ for } k\neq j.
\]
Over an infinite index set \(I\), these operators still span all of \(\mathrm{End}(V)\) (and indeed form part of a basis if one is careful with cardinalities).  **But** each \(E_{ij}\) is either:

- **Idempotent** if \(i=j\), in which case it is *diagonalizable* (its eigenvalues are \(0,1\)).
- **Nilpotent** if \(i \neq j\).  Indeed, \(E_{ij}^2 = 0\) if \(i \neq j\), so \(E_{ij}\) is not diagonalizable (its only possible eigenvalue is 0, yet it is not the zero operator).  

Hence, as soon as \(i \neq j\), you get nontrivial nilpotent operators, which definitely fail to be diagonalizable.  

Thus if you tried to mimic the finite-dimensional “block” decomposition approach (diagonal, symmetric, skew-symmetric, etc.) on an infinite set \(I\), you would run into infinitely many nilpotent blocks as well.  Those cannot be turned into something diagonalizable by rearranging the basis in a bigger infinite-dimensional space.

---

### 3. Mixing Skew/Diagonal Blocks Does Not Help

One might hope to replicate the finite-dimensional trick by grouping basis vectors in pairs (or singles) and constructing 2×2 blocks that look like
\[
\begin{pmatrix}0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0\end{pmatrix}
\quad\text{or}\quad
\begin{pmatrix}0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0\end{pmatrix},
\]
which *are* diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\).  While this works to produce a large subspace of diagonalizable operators, the question is whether it **spans all** of \(\mathrm{End}(V)\).  In infinite dimension, it will not:

- You can always write some linear operators that act “partly like a shift” or have infinite-dimensional Jordan blocks.  Such operators will not lie in the linear span of your 2×2-block plus diagonal collection.
- Even though each 2×2 block is diagonalizable over \(\mathbb{C}\), you’d need an uncountably large collection of such blocks to hope to span everything (depending on the cardinal \(\kappa\)).  In the end, you still miss the nilpotent directions \(E_{ij}\) with \(i \neq j\).

No matter how you slice it, you end up needing a lot of “nilpotent-like” directions if you want to span \(\mathrm{End}(V)\), and those nilpotent directions are not diagonalizable.

---

### 4. Concluding Remarks

1. **A basis of diagonalizable elements fails to span**:  
   In infinite dimension, any attempt to build a spanning set of diagonalizable elements quickly runs into the fact that “generic” operators can carry subspaces to disjoint subspaces, create infinite Jordan chains, shift entire infinite bases, etc.  Diagonalizable operators are too “rigid” to capture all these phenomena by linear combination.

2. **\(\mathrm{End}(V)\) certainly has a (Hamel) basis** (assuming the Axiom of Choice), but that basis **necessarily** includes many non-diagonalizable “pieces.”  In fact, after choosing a basis of \(V\) of cardinality \(\kappa\), one can construct a basis of \(\mathrm{End}(V)\) using rank-one operators \(E_{\alpha\beta}\) with \(\alpha,\beta \in I\).  Most of those (with \(\alpha \neq \beta\)) are nilpotent, hence not diagonalizable.

Therefore, **unlike the finite-dimensional situation**, you **cannot** find a basis of \(\mathrm{End}(V)\) consisting *entirely* of diagonalizable elements once \(V\) is infinite-dimensional.

---

## Bottom Line

- **Finite dimension**: A beautiful decomposition into diagonal + symmetric + skew-symmetric blocks yields a basis of diagonalizable (over \(\mathbb{C}\)) operators.
- **Infinite dimension**:  
  1. You still get a (Hamel) basis for \(\mathrm{End}(V)\), but  
  2. **No** purely “diagonalizable” spanning set (much less basis) can capture all operators in \(\mathrm{End}(V)\).  In fact, infinite-dimensional \(\mathrm{End}(V)\) necessarily includes many nilpotent or shift-like operators, which cannot be written as a linear combination of diagonalizable operators alone.
